section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need paper clips (or Connecting Cubes, as available) to measure body parts informally.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read How Big Is an Elephant?, we talked about different animals and how many of each it would take to be as big as an elephant. Now we will see how many paper clips it would take to be as big as parts of our bodies.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the terms measure and how big. Use the measure and how big Vocabulary Cards to review the terms.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will use chains of paper clips to measure parts of your body. Then we will discuss how big that part is in paper clips.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Provide each child with enough paper clips to measure each body part you will name.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How big is your foot? How many paper clips is it?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Demonstrate laying paper clips end to end to measure your foot.
Extend Discuss measurement. Note that a foot may not be an exact number of paper clips. Help children notice that different feet are different sizes.
Repeat Continue with different body parts children are familiar with and can measure, like hands or fingers.
Talk About Size Help children observe the differences and commonalities between how many and how big.
Children may need assistance in counting the number of paper clips used for some body parts. Assist children with fine motor support, and remind them of helpful counting strategies as needed.

Have children measure the same body part using different objects, like paper clips and Connecting Cubes. You can also measure using larger items like books or blocks. Discuss how the number of objects needed changes relative to the size of the measurement unit.
Review the numbers one to twenty, and the names of the body parts you plan to measure. As you name the body parts, point to each one in turn.

Connecting the paper clips into chains requires fine motor skills. Children may need additional time or assistance in creating the chains. Alternatively, create paper clip chains in advance for children’s use, or use Connecting Cubes if children can manipulate them more easily.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65172-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need several yellow, red, green, and blue Pattern Blocks for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read How Big Is an Elephant?, we talked about how many small animals it takes to make one big animal.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the word make.Use the make Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will find out how many small Pattern Blocks it takes to make one bigger Pattern Block.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Give each child a pile of Pattern Blocks that includes several yellow, red, green, and blue blocks. Ask, How many red shapes make one yellow shape? Help children compare the size of one red shape to one yellow shape. Then, guide them to place two red shapes together to make the shape of one yellow.

Repeat Ask children how many smaller Pattern Blocks make other, larger pattern blocks: How many green shapes make one red? How many green shapes make one blue? How many green shapes make one yellow? Guide children to compare blocks and then move smaller blocks together to create each shape.
Extend Ask children to name any shapes they recognize among the yellow (hexagon), red (trapezoid), blue (diamond), and green (triangle) pattern blocks.
Talk About Order Talk about the sizes of the blocks children worked with. Which Pattern Block is biggest? Which is smallest? Help children place the blocks in order from smallest to biggest.

Model placing two red shapes on top of one yellow shape to demonstrate that two reds are the same size as one yellow. Tell children the amount of small shapes they will need to create each bigger shape: Use three greens to make one red. Show me!

Challenge children to create bigger shapes using more than one kind of smaller shape. For example, How many blue and green shapes make one red? (one of each) How many blue and green shapes make one yellow? (two of each, or four green and one blue)

Hold up each Pattern Block as you refer to it, making a clear connection between your words and the task. Model putting smaller shapes together to make a larger shape, and hold up your fingers as you count how many shapes you used.

Some children may have difficulty focusing on the bright colors of Pattern Block. For these children, cut the shapes from paper so that they are all the same color. Point to each shape and ask, How many of this shape will it take to make this shape?

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65172-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need yard sticks or measuring tape, crayons or colored pencils, yarn or ribbon, and sticky notes. Create a height chart that you can save for reference throughout the year.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read How Big Is an Elephant?, we talked about how animals are different sizes. Today we will look at how big each of you are and compare your size to others. How big are you?

I will give each of you a sticky note. Write your name on it as large and neat as you can. One at a time, we will mark how big you are on the height chart. Then we will look at how big you are compared to each other!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Tape the height chart to the wall. As you mark children’s heights, try to leave enough space next to each measurement to allow for a comparison measurement to be made at the end of the year.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How big are you? Let’s measure you and find out! Then we will put your sticky note on the chart to show your height.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Have each child stand with their back to the chart. Tape a piece of yarn or ribbon to the chart representing each child’s height. Guide children to place their sticky notes at the top of their yarn.

Extend Use the yard stick or measuring tape to determine the height of each child in inches. Record the number on the sticky note as well. Encourage children to use smaller than and bigger than as they compare their heights to others’.
Talk About Comparisons Talk about using measurements to compare.

Model describing children’s relative heights. Pause after measuring two children, and point to the two sticky notes. Say: This sticky note is higher on the wall than this one. This number is
bigger than
this one. That means
is taller!

Challenge children to practice reading the yard stick or measuring tape. As you measure one child, call on another to come up and find the number on the yard stick or measuring tape that shows the child’s height. Then, ask the child to compare the heights recorded so far.

Review key vocabulary such as measure, height, bigger than, and smaller than. Use hand gestures as you compare height by holding your hand high or low and pointing to the sticky notes of the heights you are comparing.

Help children stay focused as you measure all of the children in the group by giving them pattern blocks and small paper clips. Challenge children to measure the length of each pattern block using paper clips as the unit of measurement.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65172-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need a balance scale and three cups: two big cups and one smaller cup. You can make your own balance scale using string, a hanger, and the two big cups with punched holes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read I Can Measure, we saw that we can use cups to measure amount and a scale to measure weight.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the words heavy and light. Use heavy and light Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will see what happens when we pour water from a small cup into two larger cups on a scale.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place a large cup on either end of the balance scale. Alternatively, hold up the hanger with the two empty large cups. Ask, Are these cups full or empty? Hold up the small cup and ask, How many small cups do you think it will take to fill one large cup?
Ask Call on a child to help you pour one small cup of water into one of the large cups. How many small cups of water are in each large cup? Which cup is heavier? How can you tell?

Repeat Continue to ask children to help you pour water into the large cups, one small cupful at a time. Alternate which cup children pour into. Ask each time how many small cups of water are in each large cup and which cup is heavier. Repeat until one cup is full.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How many small cups of water did it take to fill one large cup? Which cup was heavier — the cup with more water, or less water? What happened when the cups had the same amount of water?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Fill one large cup at a time, counting aloud with children as each small cup of water is poured in. Remind children that when one side of a balance scale is lower, that means the object on that side is heavier.
Start out with an uneven amount of water in each cup and challenge children to balance the scale. Ask, How many more small cups of water were in this large cup than in the other large cup?

Review key vocabulary such as scale, cup, large, small, more, and less. Review that the suffix -er means “more.” Have children point to the side of the scale that holds the heavier cup, and repeat after you that it is heavier.

Have children stand up to help you pour small cups of water into the larger cups. When each child has poured, have them continue to stand next to the cup they poured water into. Use the amount of children on each side to help keep track of how many small cups of water are in each large cup. If there are more than three small cups of water in each large cup, have children who poured twice raise their hands.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65172-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
